scenario:
Wall Street's Q4 earnings season begins next week with notable names like JPMorgan Chase, Wells Fargo, Citigroup, BlackRock, Bank of America, Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, UnitedHealth, and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing reporting their financial results. The earnings season gathers momentum in the final week of January when mega-cap tech companies, including Microsoft, Alphabet, Tesla, Meta Platforms, Amazon, and Apple, release their quarterly updates.

Analysts expect annualized profit growth of +11.9% and an increase of +4.6% in revenue growth. The sector is expected to report the largest annualized earnings growth rate of all eleven sectors, at +39.5%. The sector is forecast to come in second, with +20.7% year-over-year EPS growth. The sector is expected to report the third-highest annualized earnings growth rate, at +14%.

Microsoft is scheduled to release its quarterly update in the final week of January. The company is expected to report its earnings per share for the quarter, which is forecast to grow +11.9% compared to the same period last year. Microsoft's sector is expected to report the third-highest annualized earnings growth rate, at +14%.

The sector is expected to report the second worst Y-o-Y earnings slump of all eleven sectors, with EPS set to decline -3.8% from a year earlier. The sector is projected to report the worst drop of any sector by far, with earnings expected to tumble -24.6% compared to last year.

In terms of revenue expectations, analysts have also decreased their estimates during the quarter. The S&P 500 is expected to report annualized sales growth of +4.6%, compared to expectations for revenue growth of +5.2% at the end of September. Eight sectors are projected to report year-over-year growth in revenues, led by the Information Technology and Utilities sectors, at +11.1% and +8.0%, respectively.

Thirty-eight stocks showed up in the InvestingPro Stock Screener that are forecast to deliver growth of more than 25% in both earnings per share and revenue. Some of the notable tech-related names to make the cut include Nvidia, Coinbase, Super Micro Computer, Reddit, Robinhood, Seagate, Western Digital, AppLovin, Trade Desk, DraftKings, CrowdStrike, Cloudflare, Snowflake, and Palantir.
